results.notes:
Collected by a Wyoming Valley Mushroom Club member. I have not examined this first-hand.
At first glance, these appear to represent a species of Scleroderma. However, the interior includes thin white divisions ans a white basal area. These traits do not fit my concept of Scleroderma. Moreover, as the fruit bodies matured/aged the interior became gooey, which I believe is not to be expected for Scleroderma fruit bodies. In the one photo seen (4th down) there appears to be stem-like shapes seen in the basal areas. So, I’m wondering…
Gasteroid fungi? Secotioid fungi?
I have no first-hand experience with secotioid fungi. My understanding is these are rare in NE NA.

results.notes:
Single fruit body growing alongside unpaved road/trail through mixed woods; hemlock, birch, beech, maple. Growing from nearly bare ground; some very short patchy moss nearby.
Spores 8.5-9.5 × 5-5.5, somewhat textured but not prominently verrucose. A few of the spores appear to feature a very shallow depression near the apex; not sure if this would qualify as a plage, but examples of spores with plage (representing other collections I have made, presumably other taxa) feature a more prominent depression.
Cheilocystidia tibiiform, but slightly constricted just below the capitellum.
Caulocystidia similar to cheilocystidia (capitate) but with necks more variable in thickness, some showing enlarged base.
Gills subdistant/distant, yellow, ventricose; slightly intervenose near the cap margin.
This appears to match very well with the Smith/Singer description of G. laevis, which I believe has since been merged with G. graminea.

notes_fields.Macro:
Macro: I collected this gilled mushroom with a white spore print on 02 Jun 2020 in Bee County, Texas. It was growing in turf next to a small vineyard with no woody vegetation nearby. The flat cap was almost round (8.8 × 8.2cm) and was an off-white color. The cap was smooth and the margin with smooth. Stipe length was 15.0cm with the smallest diameter (1.0cm) in the middle getting a bit larger at the apex and base. Very little bruising was noted; only turning a faint yellow. No color change was noted after the application of KOH, NH4OH, and FeSO4 to the inside of a section of the stipe. After making a spore print (overnight at room temperature), I noticed that the cap and stipe had a few small but vivid maroon spots (see photo). The odor was unpleasant (a bit like a sweaty locker room).

This specimen did not have a well-defined volva but I noted that a similar specimen, probably the same species, that I collected about 200m away (not yet studied) did have a well-defined volva. The gills were not free but appeared to be adnexed. The spore print was white.
notes_fields.Micro: Micro: The spores were more or less round but with evidence of indentations. I measured one typical spore to be 8.71µm X 8.56 µm.

Site won’t let me propose Hebeloma subgenus Hebeloma for whatever reason, so dumping this here:
Hebelomas with signs of fragile veil present- so mushrooms are in subgenus hebeloma and not denudata, alpinum, theobrominum,
crustiliniforme, hiemale, cavipes, velutipes, sinapizans, sacchariolens, etc. Megacarpus is thicker and scaly.
The following veiled species can be clearly eliminated:
Subsection pallidae and H. salmonense-pileus not remaining white or cream
H. praeolidum- not odor fragrant or pungent
H. sterlingii- stipe interior never bay-red
H. ollaliense- fruitbodies sometimes clustered
H. strophosum- veil certainly not “copious”, even in younger specimens, or “long-persistent”
H. perigoense/pacuense- base of stipe always darkens
H. mesophaeum group- caps developing dark brown to nearly blackish spots with age and bruising
H. immutabile- stipes darken
H. fastibile- stipes darken
H. aurantiellum- stipes darken
H. lutescentipes- stipes don’t stain yellow when injured
H. affine- not growing in sand dunes
H. obscurum- veil not gray
H. pinetorum- odor not strongly fragrant
H. kelloggense- stipes darken
H. subrimosum- caps not conic, bell-shaped or subrimose when young; veil never yellow
H. pungens- stipes darken, not pungent
H. pseudostrophosum- veil not “copious” and white
H. vinaceoumbrinum- most of pileus never “deep vinaceous brown”
H. dunense- caps become too dark for this species
H. spetsbergense- caps do not have persistent white margin
H. subboreale- veil has white
H. wellsiae- veil has white, stipes too large
H. brunneomaculatum- said to have “peculiar” odor, may not be distinct
H. subannulatum- mushroom cap too large and not pungent
H. brunneodiscum- veil not gray, odor not fragrant
H. naucorioides- lacks the strong odor and gray fibrils of this species
H. angelesiense- veil begins white; it seems in places that the veil may become slightly tan or brown, or maybe that is from spore drops, but there is obvious evidence of white veil remnants in places.
H. oreophilum- too few full-length gills for this species
H. vinaceogriseum- unlikely due to amount of whitish veil. The aged caps are probably too light overall, as
I would assume that the veil color would begin white and not the other way around. Youngest specimens showed more white veil remnants.

Also, the following species are genetic synoyms of alpinicola per Dr. Henry Beker’s research, so will not be considered independently:
H. nigromaculatum, H. subargillaceum, H. littenii, H. perigoense, H. chapmaniae, and H. smithii.

Unlikely: H. vaccinum- only known to grow with willows. Appearance does not ft as well as others.
H. utahense- wouldn’t call taste “strongly farinaceous” and cap develops blotches; habitat, elevation and some features fit well, though
H. aggregatus- stipes do not seem fragile or thin enough
H. evensoniae- specimens of this sp. are from under cottonwoods and said to have “vinaceous”-tinted spores
H. luteobrunneum- gills not especially narrow among other general differences
H. marginatulum- this species is considered “restricted to alpine or arctic habitats, primarily with dwarf willows” according to Hebeloma expert Beker. Also, while generally paler at the margin, few have a whitish marginal band.
H. nigellum- possible, but considering this as unlikely because this species shows fewer lamellae, stem context is not very rubbery, and the stipes themselves mostly seem too straight; size does not fit the larger specimens well either

Spore description and more analysis to come

notes_fields.Macro:
Macro: These boletes were collected from the side of an older home in Beeville, Texas. They were growing in the moist soil under and airconditioner condensation drip. The nearest woody vegetation was a Wax-leaf Ligustrum (Ligustrum japonicum). There were a few landscape plants around, the nearest being a Firecracker Bush (Hamelia patens) that can form a woody structure. I retrieved several samples of the fungus of different ages. Being late in the day, I left the samples uncovered at room temperature overnight and the vivid colors became very muted, and unlike the photos attached here. Most of the previously green-yellow pore surfaces had turn reddish-brown. The cap surfaces also changed from orange-red to a reddish-brown, although not as dramatic as the change in the pore surfaces. The largest cap surface was 7.5cm wide and the smallest (younger) sample cap diameter was 1.5cm. Many of the fruiting body stipes were joined at ground-level. I attempted to get a spore print from one sample but was not successful.
The specimen I examined did not bruise blue nor did cutting the stipe tissue show a color change. Application of KOH and NH4OH did not cause a color change on the interior tissue of the stipe, however, FeSO4 caused an immediate change from the yellow of the interior tissue to a dark purple (almost black) color.
notes_fields.Micro: Micro: The next morning, I cut a slice of the pore structure, smashed it onto a microscope slide, stained it with KOH then looked for spores. I found small structures that may have been spores (see photo – probably immature) and measured one example. The “spore” appeared to be smooth and oblong of a green or olive color but very small at 4.51 × 3.11µm. The other “spores” I could see were about the same size.

results.notes:
Please Help! I have now found these fungi growing twice in my raised bed strawberry gardens. I don’t know if this information will help anyone to identify this fungus, but here goes: The soil is an extremely high quality mix of Coco-Loco potting mix by Fox Farm, Semi composted Alpaca manure from a farm on Lookout Mountain, Golden, Colorado, perlite, vermiculite and other premium raised bed pre made potting soil mixes. Also, the beds were covered over the winter with “Plankets” (porous frost covers), and unfortunately the frost covers were left in place too long (all the way through the winter until about April 26th), and many of the strawberry plants died, in part from some kind of fungal disease. Also, I have pine needles all over the top of the beds to provide a more acidic soil which the strawberries love. And it works perfect to keep the strawberries off of the soil while they ripen so they never rot.

I don’t know if leaving the covering in place too long had anything to do with this “mushroom” showing up, but wanted to include all of that info just in case it might have any bearing on anyone being able to help me identify what this fungus is. Can someone please tell me if this is a toxic species, or just some innocuous, non-toxic, harmless species, or maybe even a beneficial fungus? Obviously the mycelium is all through the beds, as I have found “fruitings” of this mushroom twice now in the past 10 days or so. The temps are about 90 degrees during the day, and drop to around 50 at night, and have been in that range during the fruitings. I only water the beds every other day, so even though they got too much water in the spring when the frost covers were still on, they are definitely not too wet now. I am concerned about this fungus being in a bed of plants with fruit that I am ingesting. Please help me identify this if at all possible. I hope someone can put to rest any concerns I have. Plus, it would just be quite interesting to know what mushroom this is. Thank You!

results.notes:
El género Daldinia esta ampliamente distribuido en Colombia, ha sido observado en Bogotá D.C., Cundinamarca, Boyacá, Yopal (Casanare), Arauca, Meta, Antioquia, Caquetá, Choco y Amazonas. Pasan por diferentes tipos de ecosistema y permanecen durante todo el año, así que este género, al igual que las xylarias, se les observa con bastante frecuencia. En esta oportunidad comparto a Daldinia cf. eschscholtzii, registros realizados en ecosistema de humedal (Bogotá). Ascoma sésil, globoso, de consistencia dura y color oscuro. Esporada de color negro. Esporas elípticas, lisas y de color marrón (100x) Peritecios tubulares de 1mm, presenta similitudes con D. concéntrica, pero se diferencia por tener esporas con una hendidura germinal recta y ascosporas más pequeñas. Crecen solitarios o gregarios sobre madera en descomposición

results.notes:
This very interesting collection, perhaps the first Agaricus section Sanguinolenti ever found in the Sierra, was discovered by Terry Caudle in his own backyard! His photos were taken of fresh material.

Terry originally thought that the odor was of “phenol,” but also possibly “spicy.”
I suspected from the first that this was not in section Xanthodermati, despite that misleading odor description. Dried material has no phenolic odor, and in fact the odor resembles that of bisporus. The taste is mild and mushroomy.

My macro description below from photos and examining dried material only:

Cap: whitish or pale in center, appressed pale brown fibrillose to edge, margin strongly inrolled when young.
Gills: young gill color unknown; gills broad, mature gills free and chocolate brown.
Stipe: smooth, thick and short, with tapered to broadly rounded bottom, context white, solid. Partial veil scant, pendant.
Context: white, slowly turning deep red (color similar to that found in A. benesii).

Growth habit: cespitose, buried in ground near incense cedar, 4,000’ elevation.

results.notes:
Gymnopilus cf. Luteofolius, basidioma estipitado, lignícola (sobre madera en descomposición), principalmente solitario, en ocasiones gregario. Píleo de 5cm de diámetro, plano-convexo, ovoide, cutícula seca y fibrilosa, cubierta de pequeñas escamas sedosas de color rojo violáceo, aplanadas en la superficie, que se agrupan hacia el centro; presenta pequeñas zonas de color verde-azul. Margen incurvado, entero, con zonas de color naranja-marrón (esporas), igualmente sobre el anillo, zonas que luego se oscurecen. Contexto homogéneo de color blanco en el centro y rosáceo a los bordes. Himenio con lamelas adheridas al estípite, ligeramente decurrentes, con el borde aserrulado, de color amarillo pálido y presencia de lamélulas. Anillo supero y rudimentario (sin forma definida). Estípite de 7cm de largo y 0.8 cm de grosor; cilíndrico, central respecto al píleo, tiende a engrosarse levemente hacia la base, contexto sólido, de textura fibrilosa y presenta una coloración rosácea cerca al himenio. Ejemplar de consistencia con cierta flexibilidad, no se rompe fácil (correoso). Esporada de color naranja marrón. Esporas elipsoidales. “según Stamets (1978), la especie G. luteofolius es ligeramente alucinógeno, se le conoce como hongo de la risa” Registros realizados por Teodoro Chivatá (2018) en el Humedal La Conejera, Bogotá, Colombia.

results.notes: Growing on the underside of a hardwood log in the floodplain of Paint Creek. Apothecia seated on a whispy white subiculum. Ectal excipulum hyaline and of textura angularis. Hairs hyaline, smooth, multiseptate, straight and with thickened, bulbous bases. Paraphyses filiform. Asci unitunicate, inoperculate, 8-spored, with croziers and with amyloid apical plugs. Asci measurements: (73.4) 82.7 – 95.9 (115.1) × (7.9) 8 – 9.56 (9.6) µm, Q = (7.6) 9.4 – 12 (12.5); N = 8, Me = 90.7 × 8.8 µm; Qe = 10.4. Spores smooth, hyaline, thin-walled and 7-septate at maturity. Spore measurements: (31.8) 34.5 – 45.3 (46.6) × (1.7) 2 – 2.5 (2.8) µm, Q = (13.2) 14.6 – 21.2 (26.2); N = 30, Me = 40 × 2.3 µm; Qe = 17.8

results.notes:
Found in an area where I have encountered many Ovoids before. Close proximity to a creek in an area that frequently floods. Like most I have seen, these were growing among a dense patch of creeping charlie (glechoma hederacea) with boxelder maples and other various hard and softwood trees in proximity. Plenty of sticks, branches, and tree litter on the ground with nearby evidence of collection during flood events. The ground is soft, loamy, and silty with areas of river mud present where frequent flooding, erosion, and foot traffic have left the ground bare.

The caps are hydrophanous with wavy margins as they age. The stipe has a ring and readily bruises blue when handled. There are also small scales near the base of the mushroom. Spore print is blackish/purplish/brownish.

results.notes:
Same location ans similar habitiat as obs 411548. Mossy soil comprising a cut bank along a dirt road.
This observation and 411548 appear to represent the same species.
Tried to work with one of the smaller ones seen here. Smashed some material into a Congo red mount and found cystidia.
I think the 2nd micro photo shows a cheilocystidium; tibiiform. This shows up fairly well after zooming in. Smaller cystidia (also capitate) are seen in the same photo as out-of-focus shadow-like projections.
Last two photos show cystidia of an undetermined type; long-necked, subcapitate to capitate.
Spores seemingly smooth or almost so, 8-9 × 4-5. Spores obtained from smash mount.
I think the traits seen at 411548 also apply to this collection.
